extension.valueString: This section is for demonstration and testing purposes only. There are a complex set of fields and implementation must contain the data elements identified in section 2.2 Person name of the HISO 10046 Consumer Health Identity Standard.

Mandatory. Only the NHI system generates the unique NHI number that is assigned to a person’s identity. NHI numbers are not reused once assigned to a person. Where more than one number exists for a person, one number is declared ‘live’ and all other numbers are made ‘dormant’ and attached to the live record.
The NHI number is the primary key for individual patients’ records.
The assignment of the first six characters is arbitrary and bears no relationship to the individual to whom the NHI number is assigned.
The NHI number is represented with the alphabetic characters in upper case.
A unique 7-character identifier assigned to a person by the NHI system
Must be a valid NHI format.

The current NHI number format will continue to be supported, except for the issuing of new numbers, once the new and supplementary format is introduced. NHI numbers are issued sequentially on the first six characters – eg, ZAA0067, ZAA0075, ZAA0083, ZAA0091, ZAA0105, ZAA0113, ZAA0121, ZAA0130, ZAA0148, ZAA0156

Mandatory. Only the NHI system generates the unique NHI number that is assigned to a person’s identity. NHI numbers are not reused once assigned to a person. Where more than one number exists for a person, one number is declared ‘live’ and all other numbers are made ‘dormant’ and attached to the live record.
The NHI number is the primary key for patients’ records.
The assignment of the first six characters is arbitrary and bears no relationship to the individual to whom the NHI number is assigned.
The NHI number is represented with the alphabetic characters in upper case.

Valid NHI number only
A – is an alphabetic character but not ‘I’ or ‘O’
N – is a number 0–9
C – is an alphabetic check character (A–Z, excluding I and O), calculated using the algorithm in Table 3 below
A unique 7-character identification number assigned to a person by the NHI system.

This is the new NHI number format that will be introduced with changes to the NHI system from July 2022. Systems will need to support both the new format and the original format. 

NHI numbers will be issued in sequential order of the first letter and then a randomised allocation of the next 5 characters with the last character, an alpha check digit. All NHIs starting with A will be issued first, B’s next, C’s and so on. Within the A’s the remaining characters would be in a random order – eg, ALU18KZ, AUL78CF, ARM79XB, ATD33RD, ADH48ZJ.

Mandatory when given name is not supplied.
This data element should be used for only the person’s surname, but not for their given (first) and further ‘other given name(s)’ or initials.
The content must preserve sentence case. For example: ‘Maccall’ is different from ‘MacCall’.
The text entered can include one or more spaces, an apostrophe, and/or a hyphen (eg, ‘Van der Valk’, ‘O’Leary’, ‘Vaughn-Jones’). All name elements must be encoded in a form that preserves macrons and diacritics. UTF-8 is the minimum acceptable standard eg, to distinguish the names Kāhu and Kahu
Family name must be recorded if person’s given name is not available
The family name (surname) of a person as distinct from their given, second and subsequent name(s)

This data element should only be used for the ‘Given name’ (‘first name’).
The data element for Other given name(s) should be used for second and subsequent names or initials, but not the Family name (surname).
The text entered can include one or more spaces, an apostrophe, and/or a hyphen (eg, ‘Te Manaia’, ‘Mary-Anne’). All name elements must be encoded in a form that preserves macrons and diacritics. UTF-8 is the minimum acceptable standard eg, Kāhu vs Kahu
Given name is required when family name (surname) is not available.
The person’s forename or given name at birth

Year of birth must be recorded as a minimum
The date of birth must be a valid day, month and year combination and cannot be in the future
For a partial date, the month of birth can be left blank if unknown. In this case, the day of birth must be blank
The date on which the person was born.

Consumer Health Identity Standard HISO 10046:2022
ISO 8601-1:2019 Date and time. Representations for information interchange – Part 1: Basic rules

A valid full date or partial date

The Year component of the date is mandatory.
Month is conditional and to be used if known.
Day is conditional and to be used if known and month has been recorded
Autocalculated from date of birth. This is non-standard field requested by various working group for completeness only.
Age of patient as at today.

Autopopulated from NHI system.

Gender is self-identified. Gender refers to a person’s social and personal identity as male, female, or another gender or genders that may be non-binary. A person’s current gender may differ from the sex recorded at their birth. A person’s gender may change over time. Some people may not identify with any gender.
See the source standard for more information about how to collect gender information from the person.
A classification of the person’s gender as self-identified by the person.

Statistical standard for gender, sex, and variations of sex characteristics

Consumer Health Identity Standard HISO 10046:2022

Autopopulated from NHI.
The criterion used to place a person into the classification is the sex recorded at the person’s birth.

Sex is a flat classification with two categories:
1 Male / Tane
2 Female / Wahine.

Note that te reo Maori translations of the categories are consistent with that used by other agencies
and organisations. There is, however, ongoing work to translate based on concepts and not just
literal translations.

Sex is based on a person’s sex characteristics, such as their chromosomes, hormones, and
reproductive organs. While typically based upon the sex characteristics observed and recorded at
birth or infancy, a person’s sex can change over the course of their lifetime and may differ from their
sex recorded at birth.
Stats NZ Statistical standard for gender, sex, and variations of sex characteristics
Must be able to add up to 6 ethnicities

Autopopulated from NHI system. Up to six ethnicities may be recorded. Use the standard ethnicity collection question from section 3.3 of the Ethnicity Data Protocols to enable the person to select which ethnic group(s) they identify with
A classification of the ethnicity of an individual person as self-identified by the person.

The address data set adheres to the street address mandated data standard and the NZ CIQ Address Profile.
Multiple addresses can be held for the person (eg, residential or mailing address).
The person’s current address or location details if known
Only used for reviewing a form
Only used for reviewing a form
Use the data provided on the histology request form.
The date when the specimens were collected/taken.
A valid date that is less than or equal to the current date and time.
Use the time provided on the histology request form.
The time when the sample/specimens were collected, as provided on the request form.
A valid time that is less than or equal to the current date and time.

Use the date when the tissue was received in the laboratory.
The interim quality standards require that turnaround times accord with the RCPA guideline and policy (8.2.l).
The date when the sample/specimen was received in the laboratory,
A valid date that is less than or equal to the current date and time.

Use time when the tissue was received in the laboratory.
The interim quality standards require that turnaround times accord with the RCPA guideline and policy (8.2.l).
The time when the sample/specimen was received in the laboratory,
A valid date and time that is less than or equal to the current date and time.
There are a complex set of fields and implementation must contain the data elements from Health Provider Index and local requirements.
This field is optional free text to collect contact information for the principal health care practitioner outside what is stored in patient management system.
Additional contact information for principal health care practitioner.

item.text: Requesting health care practitioner - contact information

extension.valueString:
The full name of the individual contributing to the care of the patient.
For every HPI-registered practitioner, use the name as recorded in the HPI system.
The requesting health care practitioner name.
HISO 10045 Health Provider Identity Standard (draft standard available from standards@health.govt.nz)
Must be the same as the name assigned to the HPI CPN.

Mandatory if requesting health care practitioner name is recorded.
This field uses the Health Provider Index Common Person Number (HPI_CPN), which is a unique identifying number for the health provider practitioner that is delivering the service where that health practitioner is a member of a Responsible Authority as set out in the Health Practitioners Competence Assurance Act 2003.
Identifier for the requesting health care practitioner.
The CPN can be obtained from the clinician but must be validated by the HPI system.

The name of the facility that is providing services associated with the patient’s visit.
For every HPI-registered organisation, use the organisation name as recorded in the HPI system.
This is the HPI Facility name of the requesting facility.
HISO 10045 Health Provider Identity Standard (draft standard available from standards@health.govt.nz)
Must be the same as the facility name assigned to the HPI FAC identifier.
Reference from extension on ServiceRequest. Organization should have conditional create on identifier.

Mandatory if facility name is recorded.
Use the HPI Facility ID of the requesting facility sending to the laboratory. Use the most specific HPI Facility ID available.

This field can be repeated if the laboratory has sent the results to more than one facility.

For organisations using the Ministry of Health’s legacy Health Facility Codes, refer to the Ministry’s current list of mappings to identify the relevant HPI Facility ID
This is the HPI Facility ID of the requesting facility.

item.text: Principal health care practitioner facility name

extension.valueString:
The unique identifier for the facility that is providing services associated with the patient’s visit. The facility identifier is assigned by the HPI system when the facility record in the HPI is created.
F is a constant prefix – all facility identification numbers start with ‘F’
X is either an alphabetic or a numeric
N is a number
C is the check digit established using the Modulus 11 system
Facility ID of the principal health care practitioner.
HISO 10045 Health Provider Identity Standard (draft standard available from standards@health.govt.nz)

Tissue or bio banking is when patients consent to have their tumour tissue stored for future either specified or unspecified research. Both frozen and wax blocks tissue are stored and can be used at any time by researchers.
